George Lachaunaye (BOURVIL) is an aristocrat, descendant of a long line of nobility. But since the Revolution, family affairs have only deteriorated and when Mr. Father (Jean YONNEL) played on the stock market, his family found itself in a very embarrassing situation, and its members very embarrassed.

It must be said that by centuries-old tradition, no one works for the Lachaunaye. We don't work, but we pray. And one day when the situation is desperate, Georges asks heaven to make a gesture.

And Heaven answers him: he will help himself in the trunks of the churches.

Of course, we are in a gently iconoclastic film (it is the fifth by Jean-Pierre MOCKY). We find the duo of La Jument verte (Claude AUTANT-LARA, 1959) but in opposition. Because while Georges is at his work, Inspector Cucherat (Francis BLANCHE, already a regular with the director) is in pursuit.

This is Mocky’s first foray into the world of religion. We are witnessing a rather immoral story, if we look at it from the point of view of the Law, but which is very pleasing when we listen to Georges' arguments. It is also this opposition that the scenario is nourished by: but this immorality is all the better because the star is Bourvil. There is in the latter a mixture of honesty and false candor that is quite pleasing. He happily pillages the trunks but becomes indignant when someone else does it in his place or when his friend Raoul (Jean POIRET, another Mocky regular) helps himself from a lady's bag.

Mocky has been criticized, reproached and will always be reproached for his anarchism and his iconoclasm, but we must still admit that this is a very pleasant film. The presence of the Bourvil-Blanche duo helped make it a commercial success, which was not always the case for the director. He will reprise his duet twice more: La Grande laundry (!) (1968) and L Étalon (1969).

But what do the reproaches matter? His comedy holds up and it unfolds for our greatest pleasure. We have as much fun as the actors in this offbeat comedy. Different from the others that were proposed to us, where strength remained in Law and Morality.

But from the start, Mocky had warned the spectators, just to protect themselves in advance (and also perhaps with a certain good hypocrisy), that the character we were going to follow was not someone normal .

This story is, however, very nice when we compare it to the other film which will touch this same Catholic environment: The Miraculous (1986). Here, Mocky does not denounce yet.

But this is another story. Let’s savor this film – in black and white, with the dream scene in color – as it should be: religiously, of course!

PS: This film is also an opportunity to find some figures of French cinema in small roles: Bernard LAVALETTE, an eternal ministerial notable, Jean TISSIER, Cucherat's deputy, and Marcel PÉRÈS, head of the brigade, as well as Jean-Claude RÉMOLEUX, with such characteristic diction, faithful interpreter of Mocky, just like the essential Dominique ZARDI.
